awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Educational experiences of youth heritage speakers
awd_abstract_narration:
A person’s spoken language variety affects many aspects of their life, one of them being the educational experience and school trajectory. The variety a student uses may affect their academic success, especially when the variety is considered non-standard. For example, a student may fail a language test for using non-standard expressions that are generally considered wrong in spite of being valid dialectal variations of their language. Because Puerto Rican Spanish often diverges from normative Spanish, US high school students who use this variety as a heritage language may experience discrimination or be subject to certain ideologies around their language. This doctoral dissertation project examines and describes the language uses and ideologies of teen heritage speakers of Puerto Rican Spanish, in order to understand how these practices are tied to their educational experiences. 

Gathering linguistic data from sociolinguistic interviews and focus groups, this research project has four overarching goals: 1.) to understand the extent to which teen heritage speakers of Puerto Rican Spanish use well-documented features of this language variety, a stigmatized dialect 2.) to understand their own language ideologies and those of others around their Spanish 3.) to explore the teens’ perceived academic experiences related to Spanish, and 4.) to examine the connections between the use of features, ideologies and perceived academic experiences. The research provides an understanding of how students’ linguistic practices may affect their educational experiences and success as well as providing suggestions for practical applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project explored the language use, ideologies, and educational experiences of Puerto Rican Spanish (PRS) speakers in the Springfield Metropolitan area in Massachusetts. The research aimed to identify the linguistic features of PRS use, understand the language ideologies held and encountered by students, and examine how these ideologies impacted the academic experiences of Puerto Rican heritage speakers.

Regarding linguistic features, the study found that young PRS speakers in the area exhibited high rates of /s/ weakening and coda /ɾ/ lateralization. Although the velar realization of /r/ was less common, it was still present among several participants. Additionally, participants used pre-posed infinitives and wh-uninverted questions, and showed high rates of subject pronoun presence, consistent with Puerto Rican Spanish characteristics. These findings contribute to the field of sociolinguistics by documenting the maintenance of PRS features in a diasporic context and demonstrating the strong connection between linguistic practices and cultural identity among Puerto Rican youth.

The project also revealed significant insights into the language ideologies held by students and educators. Students reported feeling disconnected from the Spanish taught in schools, which often favored the standard variety in many cases associated with Spain. This disconnection led to feelings of linguistic insecurity and diminished self-esteem, as their linguistic practices were often corrected or deemed incorrect in academic settings. The correction of non-standard features in classrooms had a negative impact on students' educational experiences, leading to feelings of exclusion and undervaluation of their linguistic abilities. Despite these challenges, students demonstrated resilience and pride in their Puerto Rican Spanish, viewing it as an important part of their identity and community belonging.

The findings highlight the need for culturally sustaining pedagogies that validate and incorporate the linguistic practices of heritage speakers. By promoting an inclusive and supportive educational environment, schools can better serve the needs of Puerto Rican heritage speakers and other minoritized students. This research contributes to the broader understanding of the academic experiences of speakers of stigmatized dialects and underscores the importance of developing inclusive language education policies. In conclusion, this project highlights the significance of recognizing and valuing the linguistic diversity of Puerto Rican heritage speakers in educational settings. By addressing the linguistic and cultural needs of these students, educators can foster a more inclusive and supportive learning environment that promotes academic success and cultural pride.
